Kafula is taking out a second Kiva loan so that he can have working capital at his new shop. He says the working capital that he has right now at his new shop is not enough to satisfy his new customers in Kanyama.
 
Kafula thanks the Kiva lenders for their support in improving and growing his business.

loans.use: To finance his second newly opened mobile money transfers shop.

loans.name: Achievers Group

texts.en:
Charles is a member of the Achievers Group in Chwele District. He is pictured with 12 One Acre Fund farmers, 7 women and 5 men. Charles is standing on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of millet and sorghum cultivation. Charles first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2010 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Charles joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and will use the increased profits to send his children to school.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Charles was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, he was able to harvest 14 bags per ½ acre! He plans on using future profits from the harvest to send his children to school and to save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Charles’s group will receive 6 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Shanzamukoye Farmers Group

texts.en:
Shanzamukoye Farmers Group is located in Kakamega North District. It is a group of 15 women and 2 men led by Judith, pictured on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of sweet potato, millet and sorghum cultivation. Judith is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access the best input prices and to grow enough food for the family.

Last year, Judith harvested 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land. She is excited to improve her harvest as a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to lease more acres of land for planting, and perhaps to invest in another business. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Judith’s group will receive 8 1/2 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of millet, sorghum and sweet potatoes.

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta is 67 years old and lives with her husband in Sevan city. Her children are married and live separately from their parents. Loreta is the only breadwinner in her family, as her husband is a first-class invalid and disabled and cannot work. Loreta is an accountant and has many years of work experience. After graduating from the State Economical College, she worked for over 15 years in an insulator factory, at first as an accountant and then as a chief accountant. For the past 10 years, Loreta has worked as the chief accountant at one of the kindergartens in Sevan city and, since 1990, she has worked as a chief accountant at the Culture Chamber of Sevan city. Unfortunately, Loreta's salary is too low. She also has her own business. Loreta rents a stall where she sells office supplies and provides copying and printing services.

Loreta is requesting a 700,000 AMD loan from Kiva lenders to expand her business and buy a variety of pens, pencils, notebooks, copybooks, calculators, hanging files, staplers, and other office supplies for her shop. She will use the anticipated profit from her loan to pay for treatment her husband.

loans.use: buy pencils, notebooks, copybooks, calculators, hanging files, staplers, and other office supplies

loans.name: Vumilia Group

texts.en:
Janet is a member of Vumilia Group in Kakamega North District. She is pictured with 15 One Acre Fund farmers, 13 women and two men. Janet is standing on the right with her hand raised. 

She is receiving an input loan for a half acre of millet and sorghum cultivation. Janet first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Janet joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and grow enough food for the family.

Janet reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about seven bags of maize per 3/4 acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested 11 bags per 3/4 acre! 

She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to buy a cow and send her children to school. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Janet’s group members will take input loans of a half acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 7 1/2 acres of land.

The field officer is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Elwaminyi Group

texts.en:
Ruth represents the Elwaminyi Group comprised of 11 farmers in Kakamega, North District. The group has eight women and three men. Ruth is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum. Ruth joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2011, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. She joined One Acre Fund to access the best input prices and grow enough food for her family.

Ruth reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about two bags of maize per ½ acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested three bags per 1/2 acre! She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and buy a cow. During the 2013 Long Rains season, Elwaminyi Group members will each receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Ruth’s group will receive 5 1/2 acres worth of inputs on credit.

The field officer is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer to cultivate millet, sorghum, and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Ramiro De Jesús

texts.es: Ramiro de 65 años es un hombre al que la vida le ha enseñado que lo más importante no es acumular riquezas si no disfrutar el amor y la compañía de su familia. Trabajó toda su vida en las fuerzas armadas de Colombia y en varias ocasiones estuvo a punto de perder su vida, por lo cual aprendió el valor que tiene su familia. Después de retirarse de la Armada, decidió dedicarse  a la comercialización de ropa en diferentes municipios del departamento de Antioquia, Colombia, pero los grupos subversivos le prohibieron la actividad por considerarlo un espía, por lo cual se dedicó a la venta de fruta en un paradero de buses de su localidad. Actividad que desempeña en la actualidad y le genera los recursos necesarios para la subsistencia de su familia. Hoy se encuentra solicitando un crédito con el objeto de comprar surtido (frutas) y realizar algunas reparaciones a su carro de trabajo. Su mayor deseo es mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia y brindarle un mejor porvenir.
texts.en: Ramiro is 65 years old. Life has taught him that the most important thing isn't accumulating wealth but enjoying the love and company of his family. He worked his whole life in the Colombian armed forces and at times was in danger of losing his life. From this he learned the value of his family. After retiring from the navy, he decided to sell clothing in different towns in the department of Antioquia, Colombia, but subversive groups prohibited this activity because they considered him to be a spy. He then decided to sell fruit at a bus stop in his town. He does this activity now and it generates the resources he needs to support his family. Today he is asking for a loan to stock up on fruit and do some repairs on his work car. His biggest wish is to improve his family's quality of life and offer them a better future.

loans.use: to stock up on fruit and do some repairs on his work car.
